Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Story: I sat at my desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, the gentle hum of my computer filling the room. The code in front of me was a mess—spaghetti logic, tangled and inefficient. With the deadline weeks away, I knew I could take my time, refactor, and make it something I’d be proud to hand off. But just as I started mapping out a cleaner structure, my phone buzzed. It was Mom. Her voice trembled as she told me about Dad’s recent health scare, her fears spilling out in a way she rarely allowed. She needed me—not just to listen, but to reassure, to be the steady presence she’d always been for me. My mind split: part of me wanted to close the laptop and give her my full attention, to be the child she needed right now. The other part nagged at the code, the urge to perfect it, to meet my own standards as a developer. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
